This species belongs to the genus Podarcis, which is a group of lacertid lizards native to Europe and North Africa.

Podarcis lilfordi is a medium-sized lizard, with adult individuals typically ranging from 12 to 18 centimeters in total length, including the tail. They have a robust body, a triangular-shaped head, and relatively short limbs. The dorsal coloration of the lizard can vary, with shades of brown, gray, or even green, often with darker spots or bands along the body. The ventral side is typically lighter in color.

These lizards are known to be highly adaptable and can thrive in a variety of habitats, including rocky areas, scrublands, and even urban environments. They are primarily insectivorous, feeding on a variety of invertebrates, such as insects, spiders, and small mollusks.

Podarcis lilfordi is of particular interest to scientists due to its unique evolutionary history and adaptations to the island environments of the Balearics. The species has undergone genetic differentiation and morphological adaptations, resulting in several distinct subspecies or populations, each with its own unique characteristics.

The Balearic wall lizard is considered a vulnerable species by the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) due to threats such as habitat loss, invasive species, and tourism-related disturbances. Conservation efforts are ongoing to protect and manage the populations of this fascinating lizard species.
